name: DC Comics & Films
description: Legendary quotes from Batman, Superman, Wonder Woman, and the DC universe across comics and film.
author: Quips Editorial

quotes.content: Why do we fall, Bruce? So we can learn to pick ourselves up.
quotes.notes: Thomas Wayne's lesson to young Bruce. Alfred later echoes this, making it a thematic throughline of Nolan's trilogy.

quotes.content: It's not who I am underneath, but what I do that defines me.
quotes.notes: Bruce echoes Rachel's earlier words back to her, revealing his identity. Central theme of the film.

quotes.content: Why so serious?
quotes.notes: Joker's menacing catchphrase during his 'scar story' scenes. Ledger won a posthumous Oscar for this role.

quotes.content: You either die a hero, or you live long enough to see yourself become the villain.
quotes.notes: Dent's prophetic statement that foreshadows his transformation into Two-Face. One of the film's most quoted lines.

quotes.content: Some men just want to watch the world burn.
quotes.notes: Alfred's explanation of the Joker's motivations. Became a widely-used phrase for describing irrational chaos.

quotes.content: I'm not a monster. I'm just ahead of the curve.
quotes.notes: Joker's self-justification during his interrogation scene. Shows his view of himself as an agent of truth.

quotes.content: Madness, as you know, is like gravity. All it takes is a little push.
quotes.notes: Joker's closing philosophy to Batman. Summarizes his worldview that everyone is corruptible.

quotes.content: The night is darkest just before the dawn. And I promise you, the dawn is coming.
quotes.notes: Dent's optimistic speech before his downfall. The irony deepens as he becomes Two-Face.

quotes.content: I'm Batman.
quotes.notes: Keaton's iconic delivery to a mugger. Became the definitive Batman introduction across all media.

quotes.content: A hero can be anyone. Even a man doing something as simple as putting a coat around a young boy's shoulders.
quotes.notes: Batman reveals his identity to Gordon by referencing Gordon's kindness to him as a child. Closes the trilogy's arc.

quotes.content: I believe in Harvey Dent.
quotes.notes: Gotham's campaign slogan for Dent. Appears on buttons and signs throughout the film.

quotes.content: You don't owe this world a thing. You never did.
quotes.notes: Martha's advice to Clark about his choice to be a hero. Emphasizes that heroism is a choice, not an obligation.

quotes.content: You will give the people of Earth an ideal to strive towards.
quotes.notes: Jor-El's vision for his son's role on Earth. Defines Superman as a symbol of hope.

quotes.content: I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves.
quotes.notes: Diana's declaration of her purpose. Encapsulates Wonder Woman's protective warrior ethos.

quotes.content: It's not about deserve. It's about what you believe. And I believe in love.
quotes.notes: Diana's response to Ares. Love as a philosophy distinguishes Wonder Woman from other DC heroes.

quotes.content: I used to want to save the world. But then I glimpsed the darkness that lives within their light.
quotes.notes: Opening narration reflecting on Diana's disillusionment. Sets up her journey in the film.

quotes.content: Only the fiercest among them could be a true Amazon.
quotes.notes: Hippolyta describing Amazon warrior standards. Establishes the culture Diana was raised in.

quotes.content: Tell me, do you bleed? You will.
quotes.source: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)
quotes.notes: Batman's threat to Superman during their first confrontation. Became a trailer highlight.

quotes.content: If there is even a one percent chance that he is our enemy, we have to take it as an absolute certainty.
quotes.source: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)
quotes.notes: Bruce's paranoid logic about Superman. Shows his post-trauma mindset after Metropolis.

quotes.content: Is it really surprising that the most powerful man in the world should be a figure of controversy?
quotes.source: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)
quotes.notes: Media commentary on Superman's polarizing presence. Reflects real-world debates about power and accountability.

quotes.content: I'm vengeance.
quotes.notes: This Batman's self-identification. The film explores how this identity limits him until he becomes hope.

quotes.content: Fear is a tool. When that light hits the sky, it's not just a call. It's a warning.
quotes.notes: Opening narration explaining Batman's psychological warfare approach. Sets the film's noir tone.

quotes.content: The Bat and the Cat. It has a nice ring.
quotes.notes: Selina's playful acknowledgment of their partnership. Hints at their comic book romance.

quotes.content: All I have are negative thoughts.
quotes.notes: Arthur's journal entry about his mental state. Phoenix won the Oscar for his portrayal of mental illness.

quotes.content: Is it just me, or is it getting crazier out there?
quotes.notes: Arthur's observation to his social worker. Reflects societal breakdown as a theme.

quotes.content: The worst part of having a mental illness is people expect you to behave as if you don't.
quotes.notes: Arthur's journal entry about societal expectations. Resonated with mental health advocacy discussions.

quotes.content: I used to think my life was a tragedy. But now I realize it's a comedy.
quotes.notes: Arthur's transformation moment. Marks his full embrace of the Joker identity.

quotes.content: You get what you deserve!
quotes.notes: Joker's declaration during the climactic talk show scene. The film's most shocking moment.

quotes.content: My mother always tells me to smile and put on a happy face.
quotes.notes: Arthur explaining his forced positivity. His mother's advice becomes tragically ironic.

quotes.content: I am the king of Atlantis!
quotes.notes: Arthur claiming his birthright. Momoa's portrayal reinvented Aquaman for modern audiences.

quotes.content: Permission to come aboard?
quotes.notes: Arthur's quip arriving at a submarine. Shows his irreverent humor.

quotes.content: I'm a friend of your son's. I work with him.
quotes.notes: Barry awkwardly introducing himself to Commissioner Gordon. Comic relief in the team's first assembly.

quotes.content: Kneel before Zod.
quotes.notes: Zod's demand for submission. Became one of the most quoted villain lines in superhero cinema.

quotes.content: In blackest day, in brightest night, beware your fears made into light.
quotes.notes: The Yellow Lantern oath, counterpart to the Green Lantern oath. Fear-based power source.

quotes.content: In brightest day, in blackest night, no evil shall escape my sight.
quotes.notes: The iconic Green Lantern oath, first appeared in Green Lantern #9 (1959). Recited when charging power rings.
